In mathematical analysis, epi-convergence is a type of convergence for real-valued and extended real-valued functions.

Epi-convergence is important because it is the appropriate notion of convergence with which to approximate minimization problems in the field of mathematical optimization. The symmetric notion of hypo-convergence is appropriate for maximization problems. Mosco convergence is a generalization of epi-convergence to infinite dimensional spaces.

Definition[edit]

Let X {\displaystyle X} be a metric space, and f ν : X → R {\displaystyle f^{\nu }:X\to \mathbb {R} } a real-valued function for each natural number ν {\displaystyle \nu } . We say that the sequence ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to a function f : X → R {\displaystyle f:X\to \mathbb {R} } if for each x ∈ X {\displaystyle x\in X}

lim inf ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≥ f ( x )  for every  x ν → x  and  lim sup ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≤ f ( x )  for some  x ν → x . {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}&\liminf _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\geq f(x){\text{ for every }}x^{\nu }\to x{\text{ and }}\\&\limsup _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\leq f(x){\text{ for some }}x^{\nu }\to x.\end{aligned}}}

Extended real-valued extension[edit]

The following extension allows epi-convergence to be applied to a sequence of functions with non-constant domain.

Denote by R ¯ = R ∪ { ± ∞ } {\displaystyle {\overline {\mathbb {R} }}=\mathbb {R} \cup \{\pm \infty \}} the extended real numbers. Let f ν {\displaystyle f^{\nu }} be a function f ν : X → R ¯ {\displaystyle f^{\nu }:X\to {\overline {\mathbb {R} }}} for each ν ∈ N {\displaystyle \nu \in \mathbb {N} } . The sequence ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f : X → R ¯ {\displaystyle f:X\to {\overline {\mathbb {R} }}} if for each x ∈ X {\displaystyle x\in X}

lim inf ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≥ f ( x )  for every  x ν → x  and  lim sup ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≤ f ( x )  for some  x ν → x . {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}&\liminf _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\geq f(x){\text{ for every }}x^{\nu }\to x{\text{ and }}\\&\limsup _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\leq f(x){\text{ for some }}x^{\nu }\to x.\end{aligned}}}

Hypo-convergence[edit]

Epi-convergence is the appropriate topology with which to approximate minimization problems. For maximization problems one uses the symmetric notion of hypo-convergence. ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} hypo-converges to f {\displaystyle f} if

lim sup ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≤ f ( x )  for every  x ν → x {\displaystyle \limsup _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\leq f(x){\text{ for every }}x^{\nu }\to x}

and

lim inf ν → ∞ f ν ( x ν ) ≥ f ( x )  for some  x ν → x . {\displaystyle \liminf _{\nu \to \infty }f^{\nu }(x^{\nu })\geq f(x){\text{ for some }}x^{\nu }\to x.}

Relationship to minimization problems[edit]

Assume we have a difficult minimization problem

inf x ∈ C g ( x ) {\displaystyle \inf _{x\in C}g(x)}

where g : X → R {\displaystyle g:X\to \mathbb {R} } and C ⊆ X {\displaystyle C\subseteq X} . We can attempt to approximate this problem by a sequence of easier problems

inf x ∈ C ν g ν ( x ) {\displaystyle \inf _{x\in C^{\nu }}g^{\nu }(x)}

for functions g ν {\displaystyle g^{\nu }} and sets C ν {\displaystyle C^{\nu }} .

Epi-convergence provides an answer to the question: In what sense should the approximations converge to the original problem in order to guarantee that approximate solutions converge to a solution of the original?

We can embed these optimization problems into the epi-convergence framework by defining extended real-valued functions

f ( x ) = { g ( x ) , x ∈ C , ∞ , x ∉ C , f ν ( x ) = { g ν ( x ) , x ∈ C ν , ∞ , x ∉ C ν . {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}f(x)&={\begin{cases}g(x),&x\in C,\\\infty ,&x\not \in C,\end{cases}}\\[4pt]f^{\nu }(x)&={\begin{cases}g^{\nu }(x),&x\in C^{\nu },\\\infty ,&x\not \in C^{\nu }.\end{cases}}\end{aligned}}}

So that the problems inf x ∈ X f ( x ) {\displaystyle \inf _{x\in X}f(x)} and inf x ∈ X f ν ( x ) {\displaystyle \inf _{x\in X}f^{\nu }(x)} are equivalent to the original and approximate problems, respectively.

If ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} , then lim sup ν → ∞ [ inf f ν ] ≤ inf f {\displaystyle \limsup _{\nu \to \infty }[\inf f^{\nu }]\leq \inf f} . Furthermore, if x {\displaystyle x} is a limit point of minimizers of f ν {\displaystyle f^{\nu }} , then x {\displaystyle x} is a minimizer of f {\displaystyle f} . In this sense,

lim v → ∞ argmin ⁡ f ν ⊆ argmin ⁡ f . {\displaystyle \lim _{v\to \infty }\operatorname {argmin} f^{\nu }\subseteq \operatorname {argmin} f.}

Epi-convergence is the weakest notion of convergence for which this result holds.

Properties[edit]

  • ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} if and only if ( − f ν ) {\displaystyle (-f^{\nu })} hypo-converges to − f {\displaystyle -f} .
  • ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} if and only if ( epi ⁡ f ν ) {\displaystyle (\operatorname {epi} f^{\nu })} converges to epi ⁡ f {\displaystyle \operatorname {epi} f} as sets, in the Painlevé–Kuratowski sense of set convergence. Here, epi ⁡ f {\displaystyle \operatorname {epi} f} is the epigraph of the function f {\displaystyle f} .
  • If f ν {\displaystyle f^{\nu }} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} , then f {\displaystyle f} is lower semi-continuous.
  • If f ν {\displaystyle f^{\nu }} is convex for each ν ∈ N {\displaystyle \nu \in \mathbb {N} } and ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} , then f {\displaystyle f} is convex.
  • If f 1 ν ≤ f ν ≤ f 2 ν {\displaystyle f_{1}^{\nu }\leq f^{\nu }\leq f_{2}^{\nu }} and both ( f 1 ν ) {\displaystyle (f_{1}^{\nu })} and ( f 2 ν ) {\displaystyle (f_{2}^{\nu })} epi-converge to f {\displaystyle f} , then ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges to f {\displaystyle f} .
  • If ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} converges uniformly to f {\displaystyle f} on each compact set of R n {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}} , then ( f ν ) {\displaystyle (f^{\nu })} epi-converges and hypo-converges to f {\displaystyle f} .
  • In general, epi-convergence neither implies nor is implied by pointwise convergence. Additional assumptions can be placed on an pointwise convergent family of functions to guarantee epi-convergence.
